headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning.  Welcome to ICE‚Äôs Q2 earnings call.  For a copy of the earnings release and presentation please visit the investor‚Äôs section of our website at www.theice.com.  These items will be archived and our call will be available for replay.Toda
componenttext:
Good morning.  Welcome to ICE‚Äôs Q2 earnings call.  For a copy of the earnings release and presentation please visit the investor‚Äôs section of our website at www.theice.com.  These items will be archived and our call will be available for replay.
Today‚Äôs call may contain forward looking statements that represent our current judgments and are subject to various risks, assumptions, and uncertainties.  For a description of the risks that could cause our results to differ materially from those described in the forward looking statements, please refer to the company‚Äôs filings with the SEC including our form 10Q.  We provide our reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures and why explanations of why we deem this information to be meaningful in our earnings release and presentations.  These adjusted financial measures exclude certain charges that we believe are not reflective of normal operating performance.  
With us today are Jeff Sprecher, Chairman and CEO; Scott Hill, Chief Financial Officer; and Chuck Vice, our President and COO.  I‚Äôll now turn the call over to Scott.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kelly.  Good morning and thank you all for joining us today.  During the Q2 we delivered our seventh consecutive quarter of record revenue and our best quarter ever for operating income and adjusted earnings per share.  We are executing on a numbe
componenttext:
Thanks, Kelly.  Good morning and thank you all for joining us today.  During the Q2 we delivered our seventh consecutive quarter of record revenue and our best quarter ever for operating income and adjusted earnings per share.  We are executing on a number of strategic initiatives and we see ample opportunity for continued growth.
I‚Äôll start on slide 4 this morning with some highlights from the first half of this year.  We‚Äôll focus on our non-GAAP or adjusted operating results, as these are more indicative of our business performance.  As you can see, ICE continues to deliver consistent top and bottom line growth.  In the first half of 2010 we grew revenues 20% and adjusted expenses only 6%, resulting in adjusted net income attributable to ICE growing 32%, and operating cash flows up 42%.
This performance is a result of our focus on meeting the needs and demands of our customers and our disciplined approach to investments.  Our business model‚Äôs global reach, product diversity, and extensive clearing infrastructure differentiate our opportunity set and distinguish ICE from our competitors.  We provide solutions today and offer key building blocks for the solutions required tomorrow to help our customers navigate the evolution of regulations and markets.
Moving now to slide 5, I‚Äôll review our Q2 results.  ICE‚Äôs consolidated revenues grew 18% to a record $296 million over last year‚Äôs Q2.  Adjusted net income attributable to ICE grew 35% to a record $113 million.  Adjusted diluted earnings per share rose 34% to a record $1.51.  We‚Äôve highlighted a few of the drivers of our performance on the right side of this slide.  Our global energy business remains strong, and growth in our financial futures markets continues to improve.  And importantly, the extensive work we‚Äôve done on integrating acquisitions over the past three years is enabling operating margin expansion even as we continue to grow.
If you‚Äôll turn to slide 6, I‚Äôll cover our revenue and expense detail.  Q2 transaction and clearing revenues rose 19% to $265 million.  This includes $130 million from our Futures segment and $135 million from our OTC segment.  I also want to point out that our data business remains a solid contributor, with record revenues of $27 million in the Q2.  This is driven by the entry of new participants in our market and the resulting demand for our data.
Shifting to the right side of the slide, Q2 adjusted operating expenses increased just 1% versus Q2 ‚Äô09.  Adjusted operating margin improved to 61% compared to 54% in the Q2 of 2009.  Our non-brokerage operating margins improved to 67%.  
It‚Äôs worth noting that we continue to drive increases in our operating efficiency at Creditex despite the soft credit market.  For example, Creditex compensation as a percent of revenue actually improved in Q2 versus Q1 despite a sequential decline in revenues.  Our strategy of retaining the top brokers with mutually beneficial agreements while weeding out underperformers continues to pay off.  In terms of customer surveys and market share our Creditex team continues to rank highly and is recognized for their expertise, electronic capabilities, and service.  
In terms of compensation expense, we believe our paper performance culture is one of the keys to our success.  First, it is an investment in our ability to execute and innovate.  Second, it ties each employee‚Äôs compensation to the long-term success of our company.  These incentives largely come in a form of multi-year equity compensation rather than a one-time cash payout.  This provides continuity, stability and a highly specialized staff, and importantly, an employee population whose interests are fully aligned with our shareholders‚Äô.  While our average compensation per employee is higher than our competitors‚Äô, our employees also deliver more revenue, more profit, and more cash per person; or said more simply, our team delivers industry-leading returns on the investments we make in them.
Now let‚Äôs review each of our business segments, starting with the performance of our Global Futures Business on slide 7.  Consolidated Futures revenues were up 23% to $130 million over last year‚Äôs Q2.  Average daily volume was 1.4 million contracts, which was up 36% year-to-year.  We believe the current global economic uncertainty has increased the level of hedging in risk management by a wide range of industries globally.  During the Q2 and despite relatively lower volatility, sustained demand from Asia coupled with economic uncertainty drove continued volume growth in crude and refined oil products.  
We also saw continued improvement from our Financial Futures market, with record volumes in our Russell and US Dollar index futures.  Ag. futures were relatively flat following sugar‚Äôs sharp price decline in the Q1 of this year.  And yesterday, we reported a 13% increase in July 2010 average daily volume for ICE‚Äôs futures market.  Year-to-date through July average daily futures volumes is up 29%. 
I‚Äôll walk through the Q2 performance in our OTC business, our eighth consecutive quarter of record revenues, on slide 8.  Consolidated OTC transaction revenues rose 15% in the Q2 to $135 million.  Average daily commissions in our Energy business rose 26% to $1.4 million.  Despite relatively low price volatility, each product class in our OTC Energy markets - gas, power, and oil - grew year-to-year.  With the successful introduction of new cleared oil products over the past 18 months we have continued to diversify our OTC business.  Oil revenues once again came in at record levels, with meaningful growth in all of our nuclear products.  And finally, in our OTC Energy business, July average daily commissions were $1.4 million, up significantly from last year and roughly consistent with our strong year-to-date performance.
In our CDS business, Q2 revenues totaled $43 million, down from $45 million last year.  This includes $27 million from Creditex and $16 million from ICE‚Äôs global CDS clearing business.  Creditex‚Äôs electronic transaction services accounted for 45% of our Q2 Creditex revenue.  Activity in the CDS Index and Single Name business remain soft, given the uncertain regulatory environment, and despite the relatively stronger performance in niche and more volatile sovereign and emerging market products.
We believe Creditex and our talented brokerage teams are well positioned for an eventual return of liquidity to the Creditex markets.  And as I note earlier we remain vigilant on expenses and efficiencies in this business, even as we work to maintain our leadership position and invest to deliver further innovation and automation to our customers. 
Turning to the CDS clearing business we have a solid sequential increase in clearing revenues in the Q2.  As we indicated previously, our 2010 guidance anticipated a gradual ramp in revenues throughout the year as we expand our clearing capabilities, add new members and customers, and await the recovery of the credit market.  We remain confident in the guidance we provided at the start of this year and we continue to be pleased with our progress in a very challenging and competitive environment.  ICE‚Äôs work has led to a sound global solution, even in the face of great regulatory and economic uncertainty.  We charted the course without a roadmap and we did so by being nimble and responsive.  We are uniquely positioned to continue to lead by building on our strong platform of services for the credit markets.
Today, we‚Äôre clearing over 230 CDS products and offer the most widely-adopted service in the US and Europe.  We expect to launch our European buy-side offering as well as clearing of sovereign CDS in the coming months, and we‚Äôll be adding a number of operational enhancements that we worked with the industry to achieve.  While we remain in the early stages of the longer-term OTC clearing opportunity, ICE has delivered as promised.  We have the leading over-the-counter clearing solution in the US today and our CDS clearing business is contributing to profit and cash.
  Just two years ago each major exchange and clearinghouse globally was in a race to enter this business.  The strives we‚Äôve made in tremendously complex asset classes speak to the strength of ICE‚Äôs clearing team, the confidence of our customers, and our robust technology infrastructure.  We constantly evaluate additional clearing opportunities that may exist and remain excited by the excellent opportunity in CDS today.
Let‚Äôs move to slide 9.  This chart demonstrates the diversity of our business.  The balance between our OTC and Futures revenues reflects our ability to serve the needs of both market structures, particularly amid a dynamic regulatory environment.  Our balanced geographic and product profiles has helped us to avoid the ups and downs of any single economy or market.  And importantly, we continue to see strong participation from commercial customers in our market.  This solid commercial base attracts other market participants and enables volume growth regardless of economic conditions, which was particularly well demonstrated by our consistent growth throughout the recent global downturn.
On slide 10 I‚Äôll provide some color around our recent Climate Exchange transactions, which closed on July 8th.  We believe this combination is attractive both financially and operationally.  The European emissions business has been and remains robust, with 26% growth year-to-date through July; and we see several future growth drivers for the European emissions business including phase 3 of the European Emissions Trading Scheme, the addition of new industry groups, and the introduction of auctioning beginning in 2011.  
I also want to highlight a couple of the key guidance points in our Climate Exchange acquisition here and then encourage you to refer to our earnings release for additional information.  We‚Äôve also provided pro forma financial information on our website.  We expect an immaterial impact to earnings related to CLE in the balance of 2010 and in 2011. We anticipate annualized expense synergies in the range of $13 million to $14 million, which is approximately a 60% reduction of CLE‚Äôs first half 2010 run rate.  These synergies come from leveraging our existing infrastructure for emissions market as a result of our long-standing partnership with Climate Exchange.  As has been true with all of our prior acquisitions, we will deliver the committed synergies even as we focus on growing our emissions business.
I‚Äôll close on slide 11 by discussing the strength of our financial model.  We have consistently generated returns well in excess of our cost of capital and our competition.  We have produced 55% annual operating cash flow growth over the past five years, and this trend continued during the first half of 2010.  We have $300 million in available cash, low leverage, and significant available debt capacity.  We believe the current environment is ripe with opportunity for continued investment and growth for those companies with strategic vision and the ability to execute.  We are confident that we have the financial means and the demonstrated investment discipline to continue to put our capital to work to generate value and strong returns with our investors.
We filed our 10Q this morning and I encourage you to refer to this morning‚Äôs press release for further details on our performance and additional 2010 guidance.  Jeff, over to you.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning to those of you on the call.  Scott provided a comprehensive overview of our financial performance so I‚Äôll take a few minutes to provide a brief overview of regulatory reform, beginning on slide 12.  The Dodd-Frank Wal
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning to those of you on the call.  Scott provided a comprehensive overview of our financial performance so I‚Äôll take a few minutes to provide a brief overview of regulatory reform, beginning on slide 12.  The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act was signed into law last month, and it‚Äôs clearly a sweeping piece of legislation.  Its impacts will likely be felt by US consumers and businesses alike in the years to come.  While a portion of the bill‚Äôs broad mandates include increased clearing and transparent trade execution in large portions of the US OTC derivatives markets, its impacts, both positive and negative, won‚Äôt be known until its implementation is completed.  
So subject to that caveat I want to take this opportunity to talk to our shareholders about how we see certain aspects of the bill at this stage.  We‚Äôll continue to update you throughout its implementation process.  The passage of the bill marks a start of the US regulatory rule-making process that is largely expected to occur over the next 12 months.  The CFTC, the SEC and other regulatory agencies have been charged with writing over 240 rule-makings and conducting dozens of studies.  
Nothing we can say here can anticipate any of the finer points of those rule-makings at this stage, but it appears that most of the rules will be implemented between 2011 and 2012.  My colleagues are already working with our customers to anticipate and deliver on the provisions and opportunities ahead of the implementation dates.
Within the derivatives title, which covers the swaps market, the clearing requirement will be a central part of the law, requiring financial companies to clear standardized swaps.  ICE‚Äôs global clearing infrastructure is a central component of our strategy for addressing new opportunities.  We have a solid head start in enabling many anticipated transitions, and we have a demonstrated ability to solve for the complexities of the over-the-counter markets.
In the last decade we took our over-the-counter energy swaps market from 2% cleared to 97% cleared.  Today, we are rapidly moving ahead in the credit default swaps market.  In both these cases we‚Äôve managed through the complexities and uncertainties of the times to deliver customer solutions that have been widely adopted and have spawned new opportunities for us and our customers.  
With regard to the exchange trading requirements for standardized contracts, we‚Äôve seen this transition occurring for several years even in advance of regulation, first in our energy markets and more recently in the credit default swam markets. Trade automation tends to be a natural consequence of standardization, and together we believe these fundamentals create a much larger addressable market.  Our Energy markets are the clearest example of this expansion taking place.
On a related note, you‚Äôll hear the phrase ‚Äúswaps execution facility,‚Äù or as many of us are calling it, SWEF, which is a designation that refers to a venue that allows multiple participants to interact with multiple participants in a given swaps market.  We anticipate that ICE, Creditex, and other execution venues will register for that designation.  Along with the SWEF registration, these venues must comply with core principles.  
These important principles are high standards to ensure market integrity.  ICE is today well positioned to meet these, having been an early leader in trade automation and market transparency.  Our technology was designed to serve the needs of the over-the-counter market via an electronic platform with extensive risk management tools.  Since the passage of the 2008 Farm Bill, the CFTC has had regulatory authority over ICE‚Äôs OTC Energy markets, and we have already implemented many aspects of what we believe will be similar to the SWEF requirements.
Finally, the swaps push out may require some banking firms to move parts of their swaps operations to non-bank affiliates.  Today, however, many of these operations already exist outside of the federally insured banking entities, and to the extent that additional trading opportunities will eventually be created, we‚Äôve seen funds and other proprietary firms raising capital to take advantage of market opportunities.  As Scott mentioned, participation in our markets continues to rise. 
Turning now to CDS clearing, one of the major provisions of the bill becomes effective 360 days of the July enactment, where ICE Trust will be deemed a derivatives clearing organization with that status under the CFTC, and a clearing agency status under the SEC.  The CFTC and the SEC will become the frontline regulators of our CDS clearing operations.  We will be actively working with our members on this transition, and we do not anticipate any issues with compliance.  We‚Äôve designed our model with flexibility to complete the transition, and we will retain access to the Federal Reserve for secure, overnight handling of our clearing deposits.
As Scott mentioned, there was no roadmap when we built and delivered the leading CDS clearing solution, though the bill now provides us with regulatory certainty that we need to continue to bring in more buy-side business.  Importantly, ICE‚Äôs model has both operational and regulatory advantages in terms of certainty and functionality.  We‚Äôre already actively clearing single-name CDS pursuant to an arrangement that we have in place with the SEC under the existing rules, and we will continue to expand these services over the next year without having to sit idle while the new rules are being developed.
Moreover, ICE‚Äôs CDS clearing solution is global.  We offer clearing for over 230 contracts and have $1 trillion in notional open interest with nearly $11 trillion in gross notional having been cleared.  Judging by the continued growth in these numbers each week, we started with the best and most legally certain model and next year we‚Äôll make the transition to our ultimate new regulators. 
One last note here is the inclusion of a post-trade reporting provision for swaps.  This reporting requirement applies to cleared and non-cleared OTC transactions.  In the commodity markets today we operate a service that‚Äôs known as ICE eConfirm that we created with global commodity market participants years ago.  We see this technology playing a role in helping the industry to comply with post-trade reporting, using its efficient and secure technology.  
This is illustrative of the opportunities, large and small, that may emerge in the coming years.  While we don‚Äôt discount the risks associated with change, we believe the overriding demand for commodities and risk management will continue to play out over the coming decade, and, as you would expect, we‚Äôll be very proactive on the opportunities that come with change.  Importantly, the strength in emerging market economies together with eventual economic recovery in the West all remain attractive secular growth opportunities for ICE over the long term.
So you can see my comments are consistent with what we‚Äôve said in the past.  We believe the legislation acknowledges the central role of risk management that ICE has developed over the past decade.  It focuses on strengthening the system through increased transparency, capital requirements, and clearing.   And on balance as a leading provider of solutions for over-the-counter markets we‚Äôre very well positioned to continue to lead and grow given the opportunities that we see today.
While many in the market feared regulatory change - for example, the addition of position limits - our performance has been exceptionally strong.  After establishing position limits in our key natural gas swap markets in January of this year we‚Äôve set consecutive quarterly record revenues.  I think this demonstrates that the overriding factors in our performance are indeed the commercial demand for our global markets.
I‚Äôll close my prepared remarks on slide 13 with a discussion of our consistency in delivering on our strategy.  We‚Äôve continued to leverage and expand on our expertise in infrastructure to serve new markets.  In the Q2 we marked the 10th anniversary of the company.  Obviously much has changed since our founding in year 2000.  We‚Äôve grown our business organically and through M&A.  We‚Äôve become more global and more diverse.  We‚Äôve enabled the transformation from trading floors into electronic markets, and we were early in identifying the important role of clearing.  In that process we acquired century-old businesses, including four futures exchanges and three clearinghouses, while building two new clearinghouses.
Today we remain unique as an exchange with extensive infrastructure to serve both Futures and OTC markets, from both the buy side and the sell side, the front office and the back office, across execution, clearing, and processing.  We also anticipated and adapted to regulatory change, bringing transparency and new reporting tools where none previously existed.  Finally, our lean, fixed cost operating model continues to produce strong operating leverage.  In the five years since our IPO we‚Äôve increased our adjusted operating margins to 61%, up from 48%. And ten years after our founding, our strategic principles haven‚Äôt changed.  We remain a growth company, driving growth globally.
These accomplishments are a tribute to the strong employee team we‚Äôve assembled at ICE to drive results.  Managing a high growth company while navigating through the economic, competitive, and regulatory climate of recent years has not been easy.  However, our senior leadership team, together with our dedicated and customer-focused colleagues have consistently delivered on our objectives and we continue to look forward towards innovation to drive consistent best-in-class results over the long run.
So on behalf of my colleagues I again would like to thank our customers for treating us with their business.  And I‚Äôd like to thank my ICE team for their work in delivering ICE‚Äôs best quarter in our history.
We‚Äôll now turn it back to the operator who will moderate our Q&A session.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, sir.  (Operator instructions.)  We‚Äôll take our first question from Richard Repetto, Sandler O‚ÄôNeill.

componenttextpreview: That‚Äôs about right, Rich.  We did see very strong participation in the Q2 from commercial participants.  And if you look at these numbers over the past couple of years, anywhere from 48 to 53, 54 for commercials and the liquidity providers are in the 23
componenttext: That‚Äôs about right, Rich.  We did see very strong participation in the Q2 from commercial participants.  And if you look at these numbers over the past couple of years, anywhere from 48 to 53, 54 for commercials and the liquidity providers are in the 23% to 27%.  We‚Äôve moved within that range so it‚Äôs not particularly indicative of anything.  I think the main point on the upper right-hand portion of that slide is that simply we do continue to see very strong commercial participation in our markets and that participation helps us to deliver the volume growth that we‚Äôve done, regardless of the overall economic environment.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so that mix change is in normal movements, okay.  Just my follow-up would be sort of, Jeff, on your OTC comments, and I guess there‚Äôs a couple parts to this.  But the non-controlling interest was much lower, you know, the negative impact, which I
componenttext: Okay, so that mix change is in normal movements, okay.  Just my follow-up would be sort of, Jeff, on your OTC comments, and I guess there‚Äôs a couple parts to this.  But the non-controlling interest was much lower, you know, the negative impact, which I think implies that ICE Trust wasn‚Äôt as profitable this quarter.  I‚Äôm just wondering cause revenues are up.  But I guess the real question is when you talk about OTC opportunities, you focus, and you just did, you more usually focus on energy and the credit.  And I‚Äôve asked this before, but are there other opportunities that you see beyond those asset classes for ICE?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me deal with the second part of your question and I‚Äôll have Scott deal with the accounting issue.  Yeah, I think, Rich, we really step back and look at our business now in what I tried to say in the prepared text, which is we have execution faciliti
componenttext:
Let me deal with the second part of your question and I‚Äôll have Scott deal with the accounting issue.  Yeah, I think, Rich, we really step back and look at our business now in what I tried to say in the prepared text, which is we have execution facilities, we have trade reporting facilities, we have clearing facilities, and we have various data and risk management tools.  And we don‚Äôt necessarily feel like we have to do everything where we participate in every one of those markets for each asset class.  We can have bits and bobs that we think we can move into various asset classes, and continue what we really view as the leadership position for this kind of business in the over-the-counter market.
I think you know, one thing that I was trying to highlight in my comments is that I think when people look at exchanges and ICE inclusive, and think about the changes that are going on in the US and European OTC markets - we really are the company that has a big footprint in those markets and has tools in those markets and derive half of our revenues from those markets historically.  So we do see a lot of opportunity across asset classes.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And Rich, on the first question, not to take up too much time on it but what I‚Äôd encourage you to do is look at the first half results in total.  As we exited the Q1 there were still a number of agreements‚Ä¶  You will recall that we‚Äôre operating a gl
componenttext: And Rich, on the first question, not to take up too much time on it but what I‚Äôd encourage you to do is look at the first half results in total.  As we exited the Q1 there were still a number of agreements‚Ä¶  You will recall that we‚Äôre operating a global clearinghouse but in two distinct geographic locations, and so some of the agreements that needed to be completed around that were not done as we exited the Q1.  So again, I wouldn‚Äôt look at the Q1 or the Q2 alone as indicative; I think you can clearly look at the first half to get an indication of how the business is performing.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning, everyone.  Jeff, on the legislation, I know it‚Äôs really impossible to ask you to project the ultimate impact, but you know, you‚Äôre really the closest to the commercial end users, you know the teams are actively helping to prepare the
componenttext: Hi, good morning, everyone.  Jeff, on the legislation, I know it‚Äôs really impossible to ask you to project the ultimate impact, but you know, you‚Äôre really the closest to the commercial end users, you know the teams are actively helping to prepare them.  I was just hoping you could give us some more texture around what you‚Äôre hearing from the commercial end user base.  What are they focused on?  What are they asking you for here as we go into the rule-making process?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure.  And this is just anecdotal and it‚Äôs obviously just one person‚Äôs view.  So with that caveat I think a lot of the, let me deal with the bank customers first because they‚Äôre the ones that have the most impact I think under the bill.  Many of the
componenttext:
Sure.  And this is just anecdotal and it‚Äôs obviously just one person‚Äôs view.  So with that caveat I think a lot of the, let me deal with the bank customers first because they‚Äôre the ones that have the most impact I think under the bill.  Many of them are not waiting for all these rule-makings and are very quietly and quickly looking at how to organize their businesses.  A lot of our major Wall Street participants have put teams together to really go through the legislation in detail and to figure out what changes they may need to make to their businesses and they‚Äôre doing that very quickly.
And that‚Äôs a holistic view, too - it‚Äôs not just the trading of derivatives but it‚Äôs also the clearing of derivatives, the reporting and how these businesses are going to be capitalized going forward.  So I think that shift will happen very quickly and well ahead of rule-making in my mind.
The other thing you probably saw last week, Goldman Sachs came out and announced their new OTC clearing FCM initiative.  I think what you‚Äôll be seeing is people that have prime brokerage and commodity lending and derivatives lending operations that really existed in a bilateral world, figuring out how to marry that or how to modify those to couple them with FCMs in what looks more like a futures type model; to ultimately create some hybrid that will sit in between.  And again, the FCM model I think will likely not change.  Many FCMs were low-capitalized businesses that had parent company guarantees.  People are looking at whether or not the regulated bank entity can continue to guarantee the FCM, whether FCM should be separately capitalized, what the rules may be in that regard. 
So I think you‚Äôre going to see some interesting changes happening, all of which I‚Äôm quite excited about and take as a positive because we‚Äôre developing tools and working with people, and modifying our footprint as that‚Äôs happening.  I think one of the great side benefits of CDS clearing, and I think one of the reasons we talk a lot about it is it‚Äôs evolving.  The footprint of how we do this is changing and it has been changing as our customers‚Äô needs have been changing and the market‚Äôs needs have been changing.  So we‚Äôre really evolving with them and it, I think, positions us well for not just a return in the growth of credit, as the market comes out of a credit crisis, but across all the over-the-counter markets.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Great.  Very interesting.  Thanks for the color, Jeff.  And just a follow-up on credit and the CDS market - I know you view the asset class as a longer-term opportunity but just given what you see from execution all the way through clearing and post-trade
componenttext: Great.  Very interesting.  Thanks for the color, Jeff.  And just a follow-up on credit and the CDS market - I know you view the asset class as a longer-term opportunity but just given what you see from execution all the way through clearing and post-trade, just where are we in your mind in the evolution of the CDS market, whether it be volumes or velocity?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: It‚Äôs interesting that what I think the large growth opportunity is in the index and single-name business, single names being corporate credit entities, and the hedging that will go on around corporate lending.  And that business has been impacted by jus
componenttext:
It‚Äôs interesting that what I think the large growth opportunity is in the index and single-name business, single names being corporate credit entities, and the hedging that will go on around corporate lending.  And that business has been impacted by just the downturn in the credit markets.  What we‚Äôve seen is the business that‚Äôs going on right now, a lot of it has been around sovereign CDS as Europe has tried to work through its debt problem; and some niche markets that are basically people restructuring legacy positions that exist on their books, exiting them or putting risk management around them so that they can basically roll off at the end of their term.
That business is not that interesting or strategic to us.  We are working on clearing it; we think it will be a good business to clear.  But the bread and butter I really believe will ultimately be corporate credit risk management, and that‚Äôs going to probably be levered to the recovery of lending.  We have a lot of debt coming due, you know, I think there‚Äôs an overhang of people that are going to have to be refinancing going forward.  I think that‚Äôs going to drive the beginning recovery of those markets.  So I don‚Äôt think we have to wait necessarily for the West to recover out of the current economic downturn.  We really need lending to come back, and I think some of that may be forced to come back due to the loan overhang that we have.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Moving on, we‚Äôll take our next question from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Moving on, we‚Äôll take our next question from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning.  I guess first just wanted to come back to the CDS clearing.  So if I look at the revenues, it looks like they were up about a third sequentially, and I think the notional cleared was about doubled I guess.  I just wanted to make sure I
componenttext: Hi, good morning.  I guess first just wanted to come back to the CDS clearing.  So if I look at the revenues, it looks like they were up about a third sequentially, and I think the notional cleared was about doubled I guess.  I just wanted to make sure I had that right.  Is that just a function of the fee caps of dealers, why there‚Äôs somewhat of a disconnect there?  And then if so would it be fair to assume the actual revenue growth is mostly from the buy side component?  And I guess more generally do you think the buy side is going to pick up faster now in adopting ahead of the rules going into effect or closer to it occurring?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Roger, that a larger factor and it was really the single name clearing, and the relatively higher fees on the single name versus the index.  And more single name in the Q2 than first is what‚Äôs helped drive the revenue up on a sequential basis.
componenttext:
I think, Roger, that a larger factor and it was really the single name clearing, and the relatively higher fees on the single name versus the index.  And more single name in the Q2 than first is what‚Äôs helped drive the revenue up on a sequential basis. It‚Äôs also clearly helping that we‚Äôve continued to add new members and revenues from those new members as they bring their positions in certainly helps on a sequential basis as well, which again was consistent with what we said earlier this year, that we would expect a gradual increase quarter-to-quarter.  And think that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre seeing.
In terms of the buy side up tick, we are now at nearly $2 billion of cleared business from the buy side.  We‚Äôve continued to see small progress each week from the buy side community. I‚Äôll tell you, the feedback that we‚Äôre getting is mixed.  Some of the buy side sees‚Ä¶  I think everyone sees that clearing is inevitable and helpful to the market generally, but I think there‚Äôs a mixed view in terms of the rate and pace.  Some expect that they‚Äôre going to move well in advance of final rules; some want to wait and see how those final rules play out.  
So I feel good about our positioning with the buy side, the business we‚Äôve gotten so far, the fact that we have a very active buy side community on our Advisory Committee.  And I would expect you will start to see some of that business accelerate through the second half of the year but then certainly as we get into 2011 as the rules become more clear.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, that‚Äôs helpful.  And then I guess my follow-up would be around the trading components.  So Jeff, it sounds like you‚Äôre saying, I think consistent with last quarter that the opportunity on trading is really more of a Creditex, maybe inter-dealer
componenttext: Okay, that‚Äôs helpful.  And then I guess my follow-up would be around the trading components.  So Jeff, it sounds like you‚Äôre saying, I think consistent with last quarter that the opportunity on trading is really more of a Creditex, maybe inter-dealer sort of model and maybe some broker platforms.  But as opposed to the ICE Exchange and CME is basically saying the same thing - my question I guess would be what would it take structurally for these products to be suited to exchange trading?  Is it just, is it more volume, is it cutting the contract sizes over time to bring more participants in so you can get a real sort of matching dynamic going on an exchange?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think there‚Äôs a number of complicating factors and just to give you the summary: we feel pretty good in the technology footprint and the customer base that we have attached to us.  And we continue to drive attachment as Scott mentioned with more and m
componenttext:
I think there‚Äôs a number of complicating factors and just to give you the summary: we feel pretty good in the technology footprint and the customer base that we have attached to us.  And we continue to drive attachment as Scott mentioned with more and more buy side coming in through clearing and then moving straight through processing and other things.  So we feel good about, holistically about our footprint.
Where trading ultimately resides and how it moves is going to be highly determined by what the CFTC concludes that a SWEF is, and if you read the exact language in the bill it is not clear exactly how the model will work.  And there‚Äôs definitely going to have to be some interpretation by the CFTC.  And so the CFTC on the one extreme could really try to drive trading into a futures type model where you would expect to see a two-way bid offer, real time, pre-trade price transparency; or they could have slightly different standards that allowed multiple platforms including inter-dealer platforms, even existing dealer-to-client platforms could theoretically be there.
So it‚Äôs very hard to prejudge where that rule-making would come out.  I will tell you that I expect that when the rule-making comes out the responses are going to be like being hit with a fire hose.  There are so many people that are looking at his as an opportunity - existing service providers, exchanges, entrepreneurs who view this as a great new opportunity and so on and so forth.  And so many different business models across the various over-the-counter asset classes and pockets of trading that I think there‚Äôs going to be a vigorous debate and discussion around this.  
And so it‚Äôs very, very hard to prejudge because I have the bias that I think there‚Äôs a lot in the OTC market today and the CFTC‚Äôs going to have to kind of wade through that.

componenttextpreview: Good morning.  Scott, question on the compensation.  Wondering what drove the difference between the guidance given early July to what you reported today, and then thinking about the margins, the operating margins as a whole, the sustainability of what yo
componenttext: Good morning.  Scott, question on the compensation.  Wondering what drove the difference between the guidance given early July to what you reported today, and then thinking about the margins, the operating margins as a whole, the sustainability of what you put up today as you look out going forward.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, so basically the guidance that we gave, we gave the second day of July.  And what I don‚Äôt have great visibility to at that point is the overall results from our Creditex business.  And as you can imagine the compensation in that line is a bit sens
componenttext:
Yeah, so basically the guidance that we gave, we gave the second day of July.  And what I don‚Äôt have great visibility to at that point is the overall results from our Creditex business.  And as you can imagine the compensation in that line is a bit sensitive to the revenue and the nature of the agreements we have, guarantees we hit, etc.  As I mentioned in my remarks, because of some of the actions of Grant Biggar and his team have taken to help make that business more efficient, we actually saw an improvement in our comp ratio in Q2 despite the fact that revenues were down Q1 to Q2, and I frankly didn‚Äôt see that coming.
I do though now expect those efficiencies will remain.  Our prior guidance was 60 to 62 of comp; I actually think we probably would have trended to the lower end or below that.   Even with the addition of the Climate Exchange business I wouldn‚Äôt expect us to be much beyond the $62 million to $63 million a quarter range.  So with the increase in the bonus for our terrific performance this year and the addition of Climate Exchange we‚Äôve been able to manage efficiencies and keep our comp expense I think in a very reasonable range.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Great, that‚Äôs helpful.  And then Jeff, just talking on the regulatory front, with the bill finalized here in the US, could you give us a little bit of color about what‚Äôs being discussed in Europe and if you expect any material differences as the frame
componenttext: Great, that‚Äôs helpful.  And then Jeff, just talking on the regulatory front, with the bill finalized here in the US, could you give us a little bit of color about what‚Äôs being discussed in Europe and if you expect any material differences as the framework there gets more set?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, it‚Äôs interesting to be a participant in both the sort of regulatory promulgations.  In the US while we have a very public debate in front of Congress and sort of real time reporting by the press on what‚Äôs going on, in Europe it‚Äôs much more of
componenttext:
Yeah, it‚Äôs interesting to be a participant in both the sort of regulatory promulgations.  In the US while we have a very public debate in front of Congress and sort of real time reporting by the press on what‚Äôs going on, in Europe it‚Äôs much more of a quiet process.  A lot of, we have had dozens and dozens of meetings with various staff people working on legislation and I think that, you know, what is coming out, and it‚Äôs in some of the drafts so I‚Äôm not necessarily foreshadowing what you may not already know.  But we are going to see that the central banks and directly in our case, the Bank of England, will have a much stronger hand in overseeing clearing operations and the capital that goes along with clearing and protecting the economic systems of the central counterparties.  
And you‚Äôre going to have a new sort of pan-European regulator that is going to really be looking at the execution piece.  So our, right now for example in Europe we‚Äôre regulated by the FSA who oversees both clearing and trading.  So we expect to see sort of a slightly different footprint.
With that said, the, sort of the broad goals I think that are coming out of Europe are similar to what‚Äôs happening in the US but they‚Äôre a little less prescriptive, at least as they exist today.  They want a bias obviously more towards clearing and they want a bias towards more transparency in trading.  I think one good thing that came out of the discussions is that regulators are seeing the problem or potential problem of allowing clearinghouses to be linked up; the interconnection of clearinghouses could be no different than the interconnection of major banks.  So that issue now has come off the table, which is I think a good thing for us and frankly a position that we strongly agree with.
And so what‚Äôs left probably to be determined really is what their OTC trading requirements really look like and what asset classes are going to be pushed more towards exchanges.  There‚Äôs definitely a movement towards building trade repositories there where all trades that all governments can have access to those.  And I see somewhat of a mellowing of the internal strife that existed in Europe where there were debates about whether things should be located on the continent or can they remain in London, and so on and so forth.  And really the creation of this pan-European regulator should cover all of the members of the EU and allow information to be shared between governments, regardless of where clearinghouses or warehouses or trade execution facilities are located.  So I see that as a positive thing for us as well.

componenttext: Thanks, guys.  Just on the Futures side, the core business, if you look at the volumes, each quarter you‚Äôre kind of surprised with the upside.  And you give some granularity on the different products and geographically Asia continues to be strong.  I guess just any granularity you can give from what you‚Äôre seeing from clients in the emerging markets or from Asia, and just how much more exposure or part of that business it is; and if you can just give any granularity, like quarter-over-quarter, year-over-year, what you‚Äôre seeing from that segment of the market.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, I think maybe as a foundation I think people are continually surprised by our growth, and part of it is just looking at how we‚Äôve positioned ourselves relative to our peers.  Most exchanges in the world are equity options and equity derivatives ex
componenttext:
Yeah, I think maybe as a foundation I think people are continually surprised by our growth, and part of it is just looking at how we‚Äôve positioned ourselves relative to our peers.  Most exchanges in the world are equity options and equity derivatives exchanges and interest rate exchanges, or a combination of those.  That‚Äôs really what most exchanges are in the world, and those tends to be the local interest rates and the local equity markets.  And so most exchanges are relatively levered to the true economic recovery or velocity of their domicile.
And while all of the exchanges around the world today are global in that they have screen distribution, the reality is that their products are regional.  And I think that you know and have probably given guidance to your customers about when to try to get in and out of those stocks, looking at the economic recovery of the local environment.
ICE is really different in that we are truly global and although our Energy business is centered largely in London, it‚Äôs really there because of the east/west time zone change.  And what we‚Äôre seeing is a dramatic movement of business that is coming out of the BRIC countries; and our customer base moving into those BRIC countries in order to build new businesses, to provide hedging tools and what have you.
And the velocity in our business and the volatility that‚Äôs coming in our business is largely being driven by the tension between a western economy that is slow to recover and a BRIC economy that is faster to recover, and people trying to figure out what that means for supply and demand.  And so you have this natural volatility.  And so the color I would give you is that it‚Äôs really, you‚Äôre really levered to this global economy and we‚Äôre also levered to the vagaries of the timing differences between various economies as they recover, and that‚Äôs creating volatility that just keeps our volumes high.
I would point out to you that we said in our statemtn that we have literally record open interest in July, so not only, and in our Energy footprint.  So not only have we had a great first half of the year; we‚Äôre entering the second half on top of really strong open interest, which we think will continue those trends.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks.  And then just as a follow-up - you guys hit on the OTC opportunity a lot, and the regulation is still up in the air and all the rules.  If you look at what the current regulation is and then what your customers are saying, like what is it w
componenttext: Okay, thanks.  And then just as a follow-up - you guys hit on the OTC opportunity a lot, and the regulation is still up in the air and all the rules.  If you look at what the current regulation is and then what your customers are saying, like what is it with ICE like that differentiates it in terms of your position and that you think you can take advantage of the opportunity - whether it‚Äôs ICE Link, eConfirm, having the clearinghouse in the US.  And then is there any other competitors out there that has something that you‚Äôre working on or that‚Äôs possibly a hurdle in terms of the competitive landscape?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think what‚Äôs interesting about us today is that years ago people came to us and would say ‚ÄúCan you list this product?‚Äù as if we were a venue for, almost like a vertical where you would list the product and it would go through all of our platforms.
componenttext:
I think what‚Äôs interesting about us today is that years ago people came to us and would say ‚ÄúCan you list this product?‚Äù as if we were a venue for, almost like a vertical where you would list the product and it would go through all of our platforms.  Today people are looking t the various pieces that we have and saying ‚ÄúGee, we could really use this here, we could really use this there.‚Äù  You know, even in our‚Ä¶  Scott‚Äôs being modest about what he‚Äôs been able to do because he oversees Creditex.  In Creditex alone, one of our customers just benchmarked us and found that we are their #1 or #2 broker in everything that they do, and our error rate is incredibly low which is really because we‚Äôve tried to push that team into much more automation and use these tools, like ICE Link and other things, to take errors out of the system.
That takes costs out of the system for our customers; ultimately they then give us more business.  And so all of these bits and pieces, even the ones that seem like they‚Äôre not as technically adapted tend to be helping us.  So we‚Äôre not looking at it as a vertical now; we‚Äôre looking at all of our businesses as stand-alone operations, trying to figure out where we can expand them in various needs in the over-the-counter market.

componenttextpreview: Good morning.  Scott, a couple follow-ups on your guidance for Climate Exchange.  Using the $13 million to $14 million in synergy numbers, it looks like the go forward operating costs, or the costs right now are about $5.5 million a quarter.  So should we
componenttext: Good morning.  Scott, a couple follow-ups on your guidance for Climate Exchange.  Using the $13 million to $14 million in synergy numbers, it looks like the go forward operating costs, or the costs right now are about $5.5 million a quarter.  So should we be factoring in about $5.5 million for Climate Exchange in the Q3 and letting that kind of bleed down heading into 2011 when those synergies kick in?  Or how quickly will you get to that $13 million to $14 million run rate?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: We‚Äôll be at $13 million to $14 million‚Ä¶ So let me turn the 13 to 14 around.  I would say we‚Äôre going to be at about $9 million to $10 million a year operating cost base as we get into 2011.  We will be there by the time we exit this year.  We‚Äôre n
componenttext: We‚Äôll be at $13 million to $14 million‚Ä¶ So let me turn the 13 to 14 around.  I would say we‚Äôre going to be at about $9 million to $10 million a year operating cost base as we get into 2011.  We will be there by the time we exit this year.  We‚Äôre not waiting till the end of the Q3 to start to take action so I wouldn‚Äôt factor in a $5.5 million.  I think $4 million to $5 million in the Q3, $3 million to $4 million in the Q4, on its way to kind of the $2 million to $3 million a quarter next year is the path we‚Äôre following.  Because again, as I talked about in my remarks, we have a very long-standing relationship with CLE.  They‚Äôre already on our clearing and execution platforms.  This is a business that we have and we‚Äôll quickly integrate, and so you‚Äôll see those synergies turn up quickly as we spend the vast majority of our time trying to figure out how to get the growth continuing to be at the level it is today.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Morning, guys.  Jeff, I just wanted to talk a little bit about the, you mentioned being prepared with ICE Trust for changes in the SEC and the CFTC.  If you could just discuss any of the mechanics that you would see changing, whether it‚Äôs moving more to
componenttext: Morning, guys.  Jeff, I just wanted to talk a little bit about the, you mentioned being prepared with ICE Trust for changes in the SEC and the CFTC.  If you could just discuss any of the mechanics that you would see changing, whether it‚Äôs moving more towards an FCM clearing model, mechanism, for that market.  And also if you could just touch on whether you think having the regulators in place could be a positive for CDS trading activity overall moving forward.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Um, sure.  So we automatically, ICE Trust automatically becomes a DCO once the bill is enacted, so that‚Äôs 360 days after passage under the CFTC, and then it automatically becomes a clearing agency under the SEC.  So there‚Äôs nothing that we have to do
componenttext:
Um, sure.  So we automatically, ICE Trust automatically becomes a DCO once the bill is enacted, so that‚Äôs 360 days after passage under the CFTC, and then it automatically becomes a clearing agency under the SEC.  So there‚Äôs nothing that we have to do - we automatically become regulated.  Those two regulators, we have a close relationship with them and so they‚Äôve been actively involved with us as we‚Äôve been building out this model, which is why I mentioned that we don‚Äôt anticipate any problems in transitioning.
But what I think the unique new piece is is that the SEC is going to have to do rule-making and figure out what it‚Äôs, what is an FCM under SEC regulations?  And is it the same as the CFTC?  Are they going to work together and settle on something that might be slightly new?  We just don‚Äôt know. 
What we do see is our customers that have large OTC footprints in the primer brokerage area moving to bring you know, their futures clearing operation and their OTC prime brokerage operation together.  You saw JP Morgan reorganize those recently and put them under one person.  You saw Goldman last week announce that they were basically creating this hybrid.  So I think our customers are anticipating how to try to handle their customer business and position themselves, and I‚Äôm sure then as we go through this rule-making they‚Äôll be talking to the SEC and the CFTC about how they think they can manage customer business.
It‚Äôs in the best interests of, the CFTC and the SEC are really trying to get more business into clearing and while there are buy side exemptions, I think Chairman Gensler has been very powerful on the fact that he really wants to try to build a footprint that attracts the buy side into clearing.  And so I think they‚Äôll be paying attention to how the lending and collateral management capabilities can be reorganized in some of these businesses.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Moving on we‚Äôll take our next question from Ken Worthington of JP Morgan.
componenttext: Moving on we‚Äôll take our next question from Ken Worthington of JP Morgan.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning.  There‚Äôs been some changes in the momentum of cap and trade in the US.  Can you talk about what‚Äôs changed, what this means for US cap and trade, and how you‚Äôre reacting to it?
componenttext: Hi, good morning.  There‚Äôs been some changes in the momentum of cap and trade in the US.  Can you talk about what‚Äôs changed, what this means for US cap and trade, and how you‚Äôre reacting to it?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure.  I think Ken, if you look at the chart we put out we showed how really the European business is the business that has been widely adopted and is growing quickly, and it‚Äôs the business we wanted to own and it‚Äôs the real value that we saw in that
componenttext:
Sure.  I think Ken, if you look at the chart we put out we showed how really the European business is the business that has been widely adopted and is growing quickly, and it‚Äôs the business we wanted to own and it‚Äôs the real value that we saw in that acquisition.  The current US business in the Climate Exchange is a loss-making business as it exists today, and we are going to study it and talk to the market about how they view that business now and what they think we should do with it.  Those companies pay dues right now and obviously a delay in cap and trade is going to mean the dues and the amounts may go up.
Let me just describe briefly: in the US there is a voluntary cap and trade business that was organized by Doc Sandor.  It‚Äôs been widely used and it is voluntary.  And while we obviously focus on the trade piece these companies have voluntarily agreed to caps and to walk down their carbon footprint.  And it remains to be seen now in an uncertain US regulatory environment whether companies are going to want to continue to walk down their carbon footprint, whether or not they‚Äôre going to get credit for it by Congress; now that the EPA oversees carbon, whether or not the EPA is going to give them credit for the work that they‚Äôre voluntarily doing.  So that‚Äôs one question that we have to ask the marketplace.  
The second piece is that we trade NOX and SOX emissions, NOX and SOX emissions, and that has been challenged by some legal challenges that have affected the way that the EPA is looking at NOX and SOX trading.  It‚Äôs a bit destabilized right now. Again, we have to survey the market and ask them how do they feel about the footprint that we acquired there and do they want that to survive?
So the last piece that we‚Äôre also focusing on is that the Climate Exchange is a 25% owner of a carbon exchange that‚Äôs being built in China, and that is one of the few if not the only non-Chinese owner of an exchange in China.  And that is a joint venture that exists with the Chinese Oil Company.  So we are very, very excited about that particular footprint because it gives us a way to dialog directly with the Oil Company there; it gives us a footprint that we can work on in China.  I‚Äôve been very loathed to have our employees flying around China trying to scare up business because of the expense and really the improbable hit rate that we were likely to have in that expense.  But this gives us something that we can lever off of, an anchor.
I don‚Äôt know how successful that will ultimately be but I do know that that is an important relationship that I think can pay dividends in many other businesses that we have over the long term.  So that is an exciting area that is a non-European business.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Great.  Thank you very much.
componenttext: Great.  Thank you very much.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, good morning.  Just to follow-up on Ken‚Äôs question from just now on the Climate Exchange, I mean historically I think you‚Äôve never been a big fan of just making acquisitions to get costs out and you gave the synergies here very quickly.  What abo
componenttext: Hey, good morning.  Just to follow-up on Ken‚Äôs question from just now on the Climate Exchange, I mean historically I think you‚Äôve never been a big fan of just making acquisitions to get costs out and you gave the synergies here very quickly.  What about the top line?  I mean what is it that you‚Äôre bringing to the table that could be transformational to this company?  Like where do you think you can actually make a difference and take this to the next level, and how long will it take?  Thanks.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, the biggest opportunity that we have‚Ä¶ We have a couple of opportunities.  One is that Europe is facing in their carbon approach and so there are some additional phases that are yet to come in that we think will drive growth.  But I think the bigge
componenttext:
Yeah, the biggest opportunity that we have‚Ä¶ We have a couple of opportunities.  One is that Europe is facing in their carbon approach and so there are some additional phases that are yet to come in that we think will drive growth.  But I think the biggest synergy that we have, it‚Äôs really a revenue synergy and so as you know, it‚Äôs hard for shareholders to really get comfortable with a revenue synergy so we haven‚Äôt really advertised it too much.  
But the reality is in our mind the people that are really most impacted by the carbon caps are the utility and energy businesses, and those are our traditional customers.  And we have been working to give more and more offsets and other risk management tools to the utility footprint so that they can both trade power and natural gas on ICE and also you know, buy their carbon.  And so that is a very, very powerful coupling.  And while we had it before in our partnership with CLE, by bringing in the marketing people and the product development people into our ownership now and control we‚Äôll be able to work much closer.
One of the first things we did after making this acquisition is move those people into our offices and immediately get them working with our existing people because we really do think we can drive higher revenue growth.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, good.  And then just very quickly to follow up on Roger‚Äôs question from earlier on exchange trading - I think you talked about the SWEF‚Äôs and how that still might be very fragmented.  But what do you think about actually new listed contracts on
componenttext: Okay, good.  And then just very quickly to follow up on Roger‚Äôs question from earlier on exchange trading - I think you talked about the SWEF‚Äôs and how that still might be very fragmented.  But what do you think about actually new listed contracts on your exchange?  I mean in particular in the credit area where you seem to have somewhat of a frontrunner position, and we‚Äôve talked to some dealers here and historically there‚Äôs been a lot of push back with Eur. ex. for example.  But it seems like dealers are gradually warming up to the idea that ‚ÄúHey, a listed product might actually make sense given that the economics of the OTC markets have been coming down.‚Äù  So any ideas or anything you‚Äôre working on that you can share with us already?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Nothing I can share but I‚Äôll just make some editorial comments, and that is that, one is the feel in the US and largely anticipated what comes out of Europe is going to push things that are standardized to become more listed in the over-the-counter mark
componenttext:
Nothing I can share but I‚Äôll just make some editorial comments, and that is that, one is the feel in the US and largely anticipated what comes out of Europe is going to push things that are standardized to become more listed in the over-the-counter market.  And then the second piece is that this bill that I spent a lot of time talking about in my prepared remarks is really regulation of the over-the-counter markets.  It doesn‚Äôt really change much for futures, and there is certainly a lot of knowledge and legal certainty in the trading of futures.
  And so in my mind it provides and additional bias for people to say ‚ÄúHeck, maybe instead of trying to do all this stuff and comply and reorganize businesses and move capital around, and so on and so forth, maybe if we had some of the benchmarks listed as futures it would make our life easy.‚Äù  So I think what you‚Äôre picking up on is people who are really getting into the nuances of this legislation and trying to say maybe there are certain aspects that should not remain in the over-the-counter markets. 
And there‚Äôll be a tension there so I don‚Äôt know that it necessarily will move things into futures, but there‚Äôs definitely much more openness to look at how futures and the over-the-counter markets play together.  We long ago saw that OTC and futures play together.  I mean one of the very first things I did after starting ICE was acquire a futures exchange and list OTC and futures that were related on one screen, and that helped drive our early growth.  And you‚Äôve seen other asset classes where never the two shall meet, but you now see people in those asset classes saying ‚ÄúWait a minute here, maybe we should get these markets closely linked together because in reality they are and regulators are pushing them that way anyway.‚Äù

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Alright, very good.  Thank you.
componenttext: Alright, very good.  Thank you.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: We‚Äôll take our next question from Matthew Heinz, Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: We‚Äôll take our next question from Matthew Heinz, Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning.  Going back to the CDS business, you spoke a bit about how the regulatory landscape is evolving in the UK.  And given your touch points in both the US and Europe, do you feel that we will need to see some sort of regulatory I guess harmo
componenttext: Hi, good morning.  Going back to the CDS business, you spoke a bit about how the regulatory landscape is evolving in the UK.  And given your touch points in both the US and Europe, do you feel that we will need to see some sort of regulatory I guess harmonization on both sides of the pond before CDS volumes really begin to accelerate on a global scale?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: You know, first of all US and European regulators have long worked towards and talked about more harmonized regulation but I really see it accelerating.  I think there‚Äôs a lot of goodwill to try to do that and it does seem now like Europe is looking at
componenttext:
You know, first of all US and European regulators have long worked towards and talked about more harmonized regulation but I really see it accelerating.  I think there‚Äôs a lot of goodwill to try to do that and it does seem now like Europe is looking at the Dodd-Frank Bill and is trying to figure out what it likes about that, what it doesn‚Äôt like.  You know, it‚Äôs going to do things that will not be identical but the goal will be similar.  So I really do see that coupled with the fact that the US is starting to participate more in the BOSL (sp) discussions.  The US has been an observer in those discussions but I recently saw where Chairman Frank is taking those seriously.  And so you can see moves towards harmonizing the capital requirements, again driving things into clearing.
I do believe that as we put more regulation around particularly credit markets that it‚Äôs going to actually increase the amount of trading because it‚Äôs going to bring confidence to the buy side. You have a lot of people that manage and run institutional money that are very, very fussy about where they will place customer money.  They want it to be in transparent liquid markets that they can easily mark to market and so I think that the institutional buy side will participate much more in the credit business as it becomes more regulated.  That will be true you know, sort of long, lonely type money that will bring more market makers and nontraditional players into the market, and so you can just see how it could lever up.  But the underpinning is going to be a global regulatory footprint.
You know, we do clear in Europe and in the US and the models that we have there are similar.  There are some slight vagaries and as we move into this new world of what OTC futures commissions merchants look like there are some vagaries right now between the two models.  But I think we‚Äôre anticipating that a lot of those gaps will narrow as both, regulators on both sides sort of look to each other to see what each other is doing.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, I think that‚Äôs an important point.  I mean we‚Äôve got a clearinghouse that‚Äôs actually up and running that‚Äôs cleared $11 trillion.  It‚Äôs a clearing model that‚Äôs been reviewed and/or regulated by the FSA, various European commissions, the C
componenttext: Yeah, I think that‚Äôs an important point.  I mean we‚Äôve got a clearinghouse that‚Äôs actually up and running that‚Äôs cleared $11 trillion.  It‚Äôs a clearing model that‚Äôs been reviewed and/or regulated by the FSA, various European commissions, the CFTC, the SEC, the Fed and the New York Banking Department.  So we can enable that type of conversation by demonstrating a model that‚Äôs already working.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks.  That‚Äôs very helpful.  And then carrying that over to the capital discussion, you did hit a bit on your expectations for the changing capital structure for prop desks and FCMs and so on and so forth, but how do you expect this dynamic to i
componenttext: Okay, thanks.  That‚Äôs very helpful.  And then carrying that over to the capital discussion, you did hit a bit on your expectations for the changing capital structure for prop desks and FCMs and so on and so forth, but how do you expect this dynamic to impact the buy side and the commercial end user in these markets?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: I think another big piece of the rule-making in the US that‚Äôs yet unknown is that we have to get a definition of what a major swaps participant is, because in addition to dealers there‚Äôs this thing called a major swaps participant that will be differe
componenttext:
I think another big piece of the rule-making in the US that‚Äôs yet unknown is that we have to get a definition of what a major swaps participant is, because in addition to dealers there‚Äôs this thing called a major swaps participant that will be different than the end user who will be qualified for an end-user exemption.  So you know, are we going to find that many of the large, traditional money managers are going to be considered major swaps participants or are they going to be considered the buy side?  And we have to, there‚Äôs a lot of chatter in the industry going on around that, a lot of uncertainty about you know, who will get roped into what requirements.  And I think until we really see that rule-making come out and get some sense of where we‚Äôre going it‚Äôs hard to know.
I think a good example though to look at is what‚Äôs gone on in our energy clearing business where there‚Äôs no regulation and everybody who clears there has been doing it voluntarily.  And what you find is that while it costs money to clear in the sense that you have to post margin and you get marked to market, and those are the kinds of things you hear the buy side concerned about in other asset classes - the reality is it nets down your potion.  And as we‚Äôve shown in CDS, we‚Äôve taken $11 trillion in notional down to $1 trillion.  So it‚Äôs collapsing at more than 10:1.
And so yes you have to post margin on the net amount, but the net amount can be for many people dramatically reduced from their notional.  And it‚Äôs that phenomena that brings the buy side in and they are willing to post capital because it‚Äôs capital against a much smaller number than if they have to have a prime brokerage relationship and post margin money against the post-notional.  But I still think regardless of how the swaps exemptions work out and how the major swaps participants are regulated that the trend there is very, very powerful.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: That‚Äôs very helpful.  Thank you.
componenttext: That‚Äôs very helpful.  Thank you.
