headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: First question, looks like the market data revenue had a little bit of a pickup this quarter relative to prior trends and just wanted to know, if you could talked all about what‚Äôs driving that. Is there any pricing? Is it user? Is it a combination of bo
componenttext: First question, looks like the market data revenue had a little bit of a pickup this quarter relative to prior trends and just wanted to know, if you could talked all about what‚Äôs driving that. Is there any pricing? Is it user? Is it a combination of both? Just give us a little color on what‚Äôs driving the increase in market data? Thank you.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. The increases we‚Äôre seeing in market data over the last couple quarters is really growth we‚Äôre seeing in users. It‚Äôs new people that want our data and want access to our platform. So as I‚Äôve said in the past, the market data growth to me is
componenttext: Yeah. The increases we‚Äôre seeing in market data over the last couple quarters is really growth we‚Äôre seeing in users. It‚Äôs new people that want our data and want access to our platform. So as I‚Äôve said in the past, the market data growth to me is a good indicator that there‚Äôs continued and growing interest in the products that trade on our exchange and although not necessarily highly correlated item, it is indicative -- it‚Äôs a good indicator for future demand in our product.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess on a related question, seem to ask this ever call but I‚Äôm going to ask again, any progress on giving us a better flavor for the growth coming outside of the key markets in U.S. and Europe. Any idea, any possibility of giving us some idea o
componenttext: Okay. I guess on a related question, seem to ask this ever call but I‚Äôm going to ask again, any progress on giving us a better flavor for the growth coming outside of the key markets in U.S. and Europe. Any idea, any possibility of giving us some idea of or better idea of what the growth that‚Äôs coming from Asia, across your platform, either through new users or any other things you‚Äôve thought about for giving us a better sense. That‚Äôs a biggest question, I get really from investors. How do we get comfortable that the growth is sustainable. What‚Äôs the opportunity outside there of key markets to continue to grow volume. Thanks.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: You keep asking and I guess I keep being not overly helpful. There‚Äôs not a specific metric that we‚Äôve got that would show it but we do see generally continued growth out of Asia. What‚Äôs difficult in Asia as you look at the metrics because a lot of t
componenttext:
You keep asking and I guess I keep being not overly helpful. There‚Äôs not a specific metric that we‚Äôve got that would show it but we do see generally continued growth out of Asia. What‚Äôs difficult in Asia as you look at the metrics because a lot of the Asian growth we actually see as Jeff mentioned in our London market with London traders. So we said that about 40% of our revenues last year came from outside the U.S. I would suspect by the time we round up the numbers for 2010, you‚Äôre going to be -- you‚Äôll see a similar or even an improved level.
Not, again, a necessarily direct correlation but I mentioned in my remarks that we‚Äôve improved our tax rate as we look forward and that‚Äôs because we are seeing growth in customers outside the U.S. doing business in our London-based clearing house, our London-based exchange. So that‚Äôs an indicator I look at anyway that says as our tax rate comes down, it‚Äôs coming down because we‚Äôre doing more business in a lower tax jurisdiction.
So I think those are some of the indicators that I look at that demonstrate that it‚Äôs happening. And our ability to say that we think the tax rate will remain at that lower level is because we think the trend will continue.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe just to follow up, when we met last week with SINOPEC, a Chinese oil Company, they are expanding their footprint with a trading desk in London. So as I mentioned, London is the heart of the oil business and the business seems to come to it as op
componenttext: And maybe just to follow up, when we met last week with SINOPEC, a Chinese oil Company, they are expanding their footprint with a trading desk in London. So as I mentioned, London is the heart of the oil business and the business seems to come to it as opposed to hedgers and traders leaving and going to Asia.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Is there any relationship between the data and the increase in users there and those eventually becoming active trading customers?
componenttext: Is there any relationship between the data and the increase in users there and those eventually becoming active trading customers?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. I mean, again, what we‚Äôve seen when I started three years ago, I think we had about 6,000 or so max log-ins during the day and now we‚Äôre upwards of 11,000. And again, I think that trend you see it in our data revenues being up over the last coup
componenttext: Yeah. I mean, again, what we‚Äôve seen when I started three years ago, I think we had about 6,000 or so max log-ins during the day and now we‚Äôre upwards of 11,000. And again, I think that trend you see it in our data revenues being up over the last couple of years, we see new users wanting more of the data now. So there‚Äôs no question as more people get the data and get access to the system, that trading volumes will trend. Again, I don‚Äôt know a specific correlation but there‚Äôs no question that they do move together.

componenttext: By the way, log-in is a point of connectivity that may have dozens and dozens or hundreds of people behind it. But those are -- we‚Äôre just seeing more and more connections coming in to us.

componenttext: Can you talk about the Climate Exchange and what you‚Äôre doing in terms of strategy, marketing, lobbying and allocation of resources since you‚Äôve closed on the deal.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think, Ken, Climate Exchange had a couple of businesses, they were geographically oriented and so I think as you know from doing your modeling, the real value of that business is what‚Äôs going on in Europe. And Europe is about ready to go to a ne
componenttext:
Sure. I think, Ken, Climate Exchange had a couple of businesses, they were geographically oriented and so I think as you know from doing your modeling, the real value of that business is what‚Äôs going on in Europe. And Europe is about ready to go to a new phase in climate change that -- where they‚Äôre going to require that more end user customers like airlines, start to buy carbon offsets.
So we see regulatory trends, particularly in Europe, particularly favoring that footprint which is where we have a dominant share. In the U.S. -- we‚Äôve mentioned that the businesses here are really loss-making businesses. There‚Äôs a very uncertain U.S. regulatory appetite for cap and trade and we‚Äôve announced recently that the voluntary market that was created had an expiration date of the end of this year in it and the bulk of the users have said to us that they really don‚Äôt want to continue to trade voluntarily in the absence of any credit for their work by the current administration.
So we‚Äôre down-sizing that market so that it‚Äôs simply a registry and we‚Äôll continue to support those customers in doing what they want to do. But the trend is the other way in the United States. We have footprints in Canada, China and Australia that came with that. Each of those is heading in a different direction and amazingly, the area where there is a tremendous discussion and movement towards more carbon trading is coming out of China. And although it is not being driven by (inaudible) or Copenhagen type conversations, it‚Äôs really being driven by the government wanting to allocate energy resources and deal with local pollution issues and carbon will be a good way of doing that.
So they‚Äôre talking to the mayors of the major industrial cities about trying to put caps over their energy and usage and carbon footprint and I think that internal dialogue bodes well for increased trading. We have in the United States, while the Federal Government is -- it‚Äôs uncertain what‚Äôs going to happen, there do tend to be growth in regional initiatives and sort of strong I would say demand for the continued use of renewables and so we have regional gas listing and also renewable energy credits and we‚Äôre with the top venue for that in the United States.
And so we do see that business continuing and that‚Äôs kind of the landscape. But long-term, we‚Äôre bullish on this and I think really if you step back on a macro level and say here‚Äôs the Chinese in an emerging -- rapidly emerging economy wanting to put potentially some carbon limits, self-imposed. That‚Äôs really I think indicative of sort of global thinking on energy.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: As we all know, obviously some of your competitors are actively seeking to broaden their presence in OTC clearing. Just wondering where you think ICE fits within the competitive landscape here and do you think a clearing solution for an asset class that y
componenttext: As we all know, obviously some of your competitors are actively seeking to broaden their presence in OTC clearing. Just wondering where you think ICE fits within the competitive landscape here and do you think a clearing solution for an asset class that you don‚Äôt have execution for could be effective?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: It‚Äôs a good question. I think, again, at a macro level, the marketplace seems to want multiple providers at every asset class. But not so many as to become capital inefficient and oddly, we started ICE with a pretty clear objective and we were not tryin
componenttext:
It‚Äôs a good question. I think, again, at a macro level, the marketplace seems to want multiple providers at every asset class. But not so many as to become capital inefficient and oddly, we started ICE with a pretty clear objective and we were not trying to make a statement, but over time I think regulators and the marketplace has looked to the competition between ICE and NYMEX. And in both clearing execution and other services and likes that footprint, likes that we‚Äôre highly competitive, that we keep each other in check and that we‚Äôve had to innovate a lot to stay leaders in that space.
So I think the market wants multiple providers and I think some of what you see going on in the background is that. It‚Äôs obvious that if you have a futures clearing infrastructure, that you could potentially add on OTC and potentially, with the right regulatory approvals give some kind of margin offset. The market would also -- and I think people talk about that and write about that. But the market‚Äôs also trying to go the other way, which is to create pools of OTC liquidity and pull, I believe some look-alike contracts that way so that it gets sort of the ICE, NYMEX dynamic going on.
So what that suggests to me is that there‚Äôs opportunities to be either the primary or the secondary clearing house in every asset class and you have to decide whether you have the Futures footprint to draw it one way or whether you can establish a pool of OTC liquidity to draw Futures the other way. And I think you could probably go through asset class by asset class of and start to identify where likely footprints will emerge.

componenttext: We were in the stock buyback mode because the market over-penalized our stock and we saw an opportunity. componenttext: Okay. Great. And if I could cut back to the credit derivatives if I could, for my follow up question. Jeff, thanks so much for your comments on expanding on the investments in the systems around, just the trading and the clearing. Am I understanding correctly that maybe you could kind of provide maybe some outsourcing services to brokers as part of if they want to become self execution facilities, but does that position you kind of out of the running maybe to expand into cliented dealer trading, because right now with Creditex, arguably, you‚Äôre well positioned to become a swap execution facility for the dealer-to-dealer trading.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: What‚Äôs interesting is that we have almost every flavor of platform inside ICE and what we‚Äôve been trying to do is standardize that code base, so that depending upon what user ID and password you log in with, you get a different user experience. We obv
componenttext:
What‚Äôs interesting is that we have almost every flavor of platform inside ICE and what we‚Äôve been trying to do is standardize that code base, so that depending upon what user ID and password you log in with, you get a different user experience. We obviously have futures and then we have ICE‚Äôs energy, the swap execution platform which is many to many, highly regulated. We have a lot of physical type markets. We have the plus windows which are an auction methodology.
And we have the inter-dealer platform at Creditex and we also have the dealer to client platform at Creditex that was called QX. And so we pretty much have all of those. We‚Äôve been investing in all of those to streamline those, to put it on industrial grade hardware, the right connectivity, the right kind of compliance and oversight around those. And we announced today that we have an iPhone app. We moved trade capture OTC over the last four months or so into our data center. That is launching today. It is absolutely real-time. You can hold your iPhone next to your futures screen or the OTC screen and you see the identical bid offer stacks.
So that is an industrial grade application that we think will further preference trading towards our footprint. So we don‚Äôt exactly know what a SEF definition is going to be and we certainly don‚Äôt know how Europe is going to deal with a similar kind of construct that they‚Äôre contemplating. But we have pretty much everything we need based on how it rolls out and the nice thing as you alluded to that Creditex gave us an opportunity to really understand the broker space, understand the work flow, understand how pays and collects work there, billing and what have you, what a broker needs on their screen and we have been investing in that this entire time, so that we could roll out platforms widely or we could keep them very narrow, depending upon what the law contemplates and where we may be able to maximize our revenue.

componenttext: Good morning. Just a quick one on SEFs. When you think about the dialogue around defining SEFs, is there a component or two of that dialogue that you believe is concerning that could be a threat to your business that you‚Äôre watching real closely and on the opposite hand, if there is some component that you see as potentially benefiting you in a bigger way?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: We have really laid out a number of internal business road maps depending upon what happens and all of them are positive for us. So really don‚Äôt see anything negative. Going to extremes, on the one hand SEFs may be very difficult to set up, require trem
componenttext:
We have really laid out a number of internal business road maps depending upon what happens and all of them are positive for us. So really don‚Äôt see anything negative. Going to extremes, on the one hand SEFs may be very difficult to set up, require tremendous complexity and regulatory oversight and what have you, in which case the market may gravitate to what looks more like a futures model and brokers would be accessing broker functionality on one or two major platforms.
Again, you could see sort of this futures style evolution which I think is - Dodd-Frank was trying to intend to push the market in the U.S. Or if the standards are low and you have -- we have 422 brokerage companies that have access to us, you could imagine 422 websites, for example, low tech things where there‚Äôs transparency and the reality is the market probably wouldn‚Äôt change much in terms of its basic business structure, other than the fact that there would be the ability to be more transparent as people ultimately upload those trades on a consolidated tape that is part of Dodd-Frank.

componenttext: I think one of the important points to make is, what we‚Äôve done is we‚Äôve cut the brokers who weren‚Äôt getting the job done. We worked well to lock down the others. We‚Äôve restructured other parts of the business. So what you see in our ability in a very low revenue declining revenue environment is we‚Äôve held on to the better brokers. We‚Äôve restructured the non-broker part of the business and all of that has combined to help us position the company, I think Jeff said it well, so that when the market does recover you‚Äôll see even greater margin expansion than you typically would in a broker business.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, good morning. One quick question for you guys. Can you talk about the CPC and SEC‚Äôs proposals about ownership and overall limits that they‚Äôre going to put on banks as far as clearing houses and SEFs. I know that you guys -- your position is it pr
componenttext: Hey, good morning. One quick question for you guys. Can you talk about the CPC and SEC‚Äôs proposals about ownership and overall limits that they‚Äôre going to put on banks as far as clearing houses and SEFs. I know that you guys -- your position is it probably shouldn‚Äôt impact ICE trust but if you could go into a little more detail on that, I would appreciate it.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Just looking at the proposal as it was drafted, it doesn‚Äôt seem to have any impact on ICE Trusts or any of our clearing houses and at ICE Trust, specifically, the business is 100% owned by ICE. We have a royalty revenue share component that‚Äôs em
componenttext:
Sure. Just looking at the proposal as it was drafted, it doesn‚Äôt seem to have any impact on ICE Trusts or any of our clearing houses and at ICE Trust, specifically, the business is 100% owned by ICE. We have a royalty revenue share component that‚Äôs embedded in a security that these guys hold that give them -- that the original holders of the clearing corporation hold as part of that acquisition. And we have advisory committees, both the buy side and the risk management group, so two advisory committees that advise the Board and the Board has the ultimate say in those things.
The board is constituted as a majority of independents as defined by the NYSE independence standards for public companies. There is some talk about maybe having different independent standards around SEFs and clearing houses and what have you. So we‚Äôre not exactly sure how that will play out, but our thinking is an NYSE independent director is a pretty high standard.
So we don‚Äôt see really any potential changes needed to our footprint. If there were, I‚Äôm sure we would -- if things change, we‚Äôve got very good relationship with our users and have been accomplishing the goals that users set out, particularly with respect to ICE trust, which was to get a footprint in place to start to get risk off the books and that‚Äôs been happening.

componenttextpreview: All right. That‚Äôs helpful.
componenttext: All right. That‚Äôs helpful.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: I‚Äôll shift gears here to another one of your businesses that‚Äôs doing really well. The U.S. dollar index has been a huge grower and I know you guys have focused on building up that OpEx business and your peers also had a very good run in. But are you s
componenttext: I‚Äôll shift gears here to another one of your businesses that‚Äôs doing really well. The U.S. dollar index has been a huge grower and I know you guys have focused on building up that OpEx business and your peers also had a very good run in. But are you seeing sort of transition to the futures market ahead of the peer business or are you guys doing something that‚Äôs even different than that to really grow that business?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. What we‚Äôre doing is that we‚Äôre focused on the U.S. dollar index as a very simple, easy to understand way for people to participate in foreign exchange. And the U.S. dollar index at its heart is simply -- you think the dollar‚Äôs getting stronger
componenttext:
Yeah. What we‚Äôre doing is that we‚Äôre focused on the U.S. dollar index as a very simple, easy to understand way for people to participate in foreign exchange. And the U.S. dollar index at its heart is simply -- you think the dollar‚Äôs getting stronger or weaker versus the rest of the world. And most FX as you know is traded in currency pairs. So for a person to hedge or speculate around the strengthening of the dollar you‚Äôve got to ask yourself, compared to what, which means if you want to trade dollar, yen, you better have some intimate knowledge of what‚Äôs going on in Japan and figure out the relative merit.
The dollar index just allows you to have a gut instinct over, is the dollar strengthening or weakening? And so it appeals to retail traders. It appeals to corporates that want a simple way of hedging their exposure and that‚Äôs the way we‚Äôre marketing it. We benefit from the fact that the press also views it in that regard. And Kelly talk about it every morning when he‚Äôs on the floor and it‚Äôs usually talked about before the market opens. It‚Äôs an easy way to get your arms around that concept of strengthening or weakening of the U.S. dollar.
And so we put more marketing muscle into selling it that way and it‚Äôs really picked up and it‚Äôs a nice contract for us and it does give us exposure to the FX space, to FX traders, to algorithmic traders that can decompose the index. So there have been some positive spillover impacts for us as well.

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just lastly, your revenues were up something like 17% year-to-date over year-to-date last year. Your comp is only up I think 7%. So you‚Äôre getting great margin expansion there. Last year‚Äôs fourth quarter you guys had a little bit
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just lastly, your revenues were up something like 17% year-to-date over year-to-date last year. Your comp is only up I think 7%. So you‚Äôre getting great margin expansion there. Last year‚Äôs fourth quarter you guys had a little bit of a bump in comp. How should we be thinking about that for the fourth quarter this year?

headline: IntercontinentalExchange, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-01-2010

componenttext:
The last year in the fourth quarter, we had a blow-out quarter and the paper performance nature of our bonus system had to be caught up in the quarter. So I think -- I hope we have, frankly, another blow-out fourth quarter and see the bonus go accordingly. But I think we‚Äôve done a good job giving you guidance on the comp. We were at 62 to 63. We just took it down from those levels by $3 to $4 million.
We talked about the efforts we made at Creditex to manage the broker expenses there. I told you that we started at 66 people at CLE. We‚Äôll be down by two-thirds by the end of this year. So I think if you look, we‚Äôve been very stable over the first three quarters. We‚Äôve given guidance and improved guidance recently, so no surprises. I expect we will continue to manage it quite well in the fourth quarter of this year.
